awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Technology to Review Online Videos for Education (TROVE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Online videos are becoming increasingly popular with young children. This presents a challenge for parents and educators who want them to watch educational videos but may lack the ability or time to distinguish educational from non-educational content within the rapidly growing universe of online video. To our knowledge, there are currently no machine learning methods for classifying educational video content; current methods rely on humans to identify video content. But human content reviews cannot keep pace when, on average, approximately 500 hours of content are uploaded to YouTube every minute. The goal of this project is to develop Technology to Review Online Videos for Education (TROVE), a machine learning-based tool to identify early childhood mathematics content in a high volume of videos. This capability will enable new approaches to increase young children’s exposure to developmentally appropriate mathematics content in videos, which has been shown to improve mathematics learning outcomes. TROVE will lay the groundwork to identify a range of subjects in videos, including literacy, science, and social-emotional content. Further, the technological advances developed under this project will have applications in other fields, including adaptive learning, social media analytics, propaganda detection, and video summarization. 

Our multidisciplinary team of education and machine learning researchers will develop a content classification engine to identify mathematics content in online videos. We will define developmentally appropriate mathematics content at the toddler, preschool, and kindergarten levels based on the Head Start Early Learning Outcomes Framework and Common Core State Standards. To train the content classification engine, researchers who have demonstrated reliability in identifying the target mathematics content will annotate the mathematics content in 100 hours of online videos. The project’s central research question asks, how accurately can the content classification engine identify early childhood mathematics content in videos, as compared to humans? To answer this, we will compare the mathematics content identified by TROVE to that identified by researchers in a set of videos that were not used to train the classification engine. We will share our findings with education technology researchers and developers, educators, and policymakers via a peer-reviewed journal article and blog post. TROVE has transformative potential to support young children’s learning through exposure to high-quality, developmentally appropriate educational videos. Further, this technology may enable large-scale research on the impacts of children’s exposure to educational and non-educational video content.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Using high-quality educational media has been shown to support young children’s early math skills. As young children have begun watching more online videos than television programs, it has become more difficult for parents and educators to identify high-quality, age-appropriate videos to support young children’s learning. To help parents increase children’s exposure to high-quality early math videos online, we developed a machine learning tool to automatically detect prekindergarten and kindergarten math content in online videos for young children, called Assisting Parents to Review Online Videos for Education, Prekindergarten and Kindergarten-Math (APPROVE PreK & K-Math). APPROVE PreK & K-Math detects math content aligned to the Common Core State Standards for kindergarten and the Head Start Early Learning Outcomes Framework for prekindergarten.

 

APPROVE PreK & K-Math uses a multimodal content understanding framework to analyze videos based on a combination of visual and audio cues. We first extract a given video’s visual and audio information, then develop separate machine learning models to classify videos based on each modality separately, and finally combine the classifications derived from individual modalities to generate final multimodal content classifications.

Findings answer three questions. (1) How accurately can the machine learning model detect early math content in online videos? The machine learning model is 83% to 87% accurate in detecting early math content in online videos on average. In other words, if both human annotators and the model identified 100 early math content categories across the same sample of videos, they would be in agreement on 83 to 87 of those category classifications. (2) How accurately can the machine learning model detect indicators of educational quality in online videos? The machine learning model demonstrated variable accuracy (27-95%) for detecting five indicators of educational quality, as compared to human annotators. Accuracy was highest for detecting videos whose purpose is to teach early math. This is unsurprising, as videos in this sample are screened to include early math content. By contrast, accuracy was lowest for detecting videos that use math to solve authentic problems. We find that few videos on YouTube use real-life problems to teach early math, so there were fewer examples of this quality indicator on which to train the model. (3) To what extent do early math content and indicators of educational quality overlap in online videos? 79% of videos in our dataset that included at least one early math content category also included at least one educational quality indicator.

 

Broader impacts: We envision applications of APPROVE PreK & K-Math for parents and educators. We could develop APPROVE PreK & K Math as a recommendation tool for families. The tool would recommend online videos to children based on pre-set parental preferences for specific early math content. Second, teachers might use APPROVE PreK & K-Math to select grade- and standards-aligned videos to complement classroom math instruction, or to support instruction during school closures due to a natural disaster or pandemic. Using videos to support preschool math instruction is associated with stronger math performance for young children (Rosenfeld et al., 2019).

 

Intellectual merit: APPROVE PreK & K-Math’s automatic educational video content detection may enable children’s media researchers to answer important questions about the role of online video exposure in children’s early math development. While much is known about learning gains associated with exposure to high-quality educational media such as Sesame Street (Mares & Pan, 2013), to date nothing is known about the effects of exposure to user-generated videos. Having a scalable way to understand the content of user-generated videos will enable this line of research. Further, to our knowledge, this project is the first machine learning application to classify videos at a fine-grained level based on learning standards. This represents a technological advance in automatic fine-grained video classification, with applications for other fields including adaptive learning, social media analytics, propaganda detection in online media and news, and video summarization.
